thread.title: Wasn't meant to be for Dale Earnhardt Jr. at Talladega
thread.title_full: Wasn't meant to be for Dale Earnhardt Jr. at Talladega

title: Wasn't meant to be for Dale Earnhardt Jr. at Talladega
text:
Brad Keselowski knows all about Talladega TALLADEGA, ALA. - 
The third consecutive Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship win by Joey Logano and the No. 22 Team Penske Ford was truly something to celebrate on Sunday at Talladega Superspeedway. 
That being said, it is almost impossible not to feel that the gods of racing have something against Dale Earnhardt Jr. 
For the second year in a row Earnhardt comes away from Talladega — a track where he has six race wins — without a Chase win and as a result he finds himself on the outside looking in as the next playoff round opens at Martinsville Speedway in six days. 
All of this after a day where Earnhardt was clearly the class of the field. 
He led 61 of the 188 laps around the 2.66-mile banked Talladega oval. 
On the final pair of restarts, that turned out not to be restarts at all, Earnhardt was beside Logano, who had Jeff Gordon in the No. 24 Chevrolet pushing him, while Brad Keselowski in the No. 2 Ford was behind Earnhardt. 
While Gordon pushed Logano, Keselowski didn’t appear to be nearly as aggressive helping Earnhardt and that was to be expected because, after all, Logano is his teammate over in the Penske garage. 
After the first foiled restart when Logano was in front as Jimmie Johnson spun there was all kinds of chatter claiming NASCAR wanted Earnhardt to win. 
Even Logano was heard in his in car radio saying it was a “Dale Jr. rule.” 
Well, if NASCAR really wanted to make sure Earnhardt won, it did a terrible job of pulling it off because it handed Logano the win on the final, final restart by ending the racing under caution. 
So Earnhardt, NASCAR’s most popular driver by a country mile, misses another chance at glory, the same story that has played out pretty much his whole career. 
Yet there he was when it was all over and done playing the part of the perfect company man, without a hint of anger at his fate. 
“I just wanted to go out there, whatever happened, put forth a good account of myself, my team,” Earnhardt said. “I’m real proud of what we did today. So I can feel good about that. 
“I can look back on a lot of different things that put me in this situation right now, starting with the first two races in this round where we didn’t run well. We got wrecked by (Carl Edwards at Charlotte), and just didn’t run well at Kansas.” 
As for the new NASCAR rule on green, white, checkered restarts that contributed to his loss at Talladega, Earnhardt didn’t feel any malice towards the sanctioning body. 
“I’m fine with it,” he said. “I feel like no matter the rules, when the race is over, I can live with the result as long as everyone else is going by the same rules. 
“I finished second. I’m OK with that. 
“We could argue they could have waited another hundred feet to throw the caution, but they didn’t have to. 
“They threw it when they needed to. I’m fine with that.” 
Earnhardt said rather than hang his head for the remaining four Chase races, he intends to go out, and like he did last season, win one of them, even if it really won’t count. 
“The best thing that could happen for us is the same thing that happened last year, go win,” he said. We’re disappointed today; we were disappointed last year when we left Talladega. 
“But we went to Martinsville and sort of surprised ourselves with our first win there. 
“Dang, you know, when I look at that video (last year) of all of us jumping up and down on that trailer like idiots, that’s a team that’s not too bothered being knocked out of the Chase right there. 
“If we can go to the racetrack and win, it certainly makes our situation much more bearable. If we could go to Homestead and run well, I’d love to win there. Never won there. I like that track. Running against the wall is a lot of fun. We’ll see.” 
For his part Logano said he knew that to win at Talladega he would have to defeat one of best big track race car drivers in history in Earnhardt. 
“Obviously he was very fast; he had a very fast race car.” Logano said of Earnhardt. “Could we have held him off? Of course. We were fighting him hard. 
“Would it have been easy? No. It was going to be very challenging. 
“We were racing against the best Speedway racer that we know, right? He’s won a ton of these Speedway races. I look at him as one of the best Speedway racers. 
“To race against him for a win was not going to be easy. But to come out with a checkered flag meant a lot.” 
The final word goes to Earnhardt. 
“Yeah, I’m glad this weekend’s over with.” 
Harvick may be penalized for crash 
NASCAR may not be finished yet with how the CampingWorld.com 500 ended at Talladega Superspeedway on Sunday. 
The race was stopped by a caution on the final restart when Kevin Harvick moved up the track in the No. 4 Chevrolet and wrecked the No. 6 Ford of Trevor Bayne. 
The move allowed Harvick to finish 15th and it also allowed him to advance to the next round of the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship. 
There is speculation that NASCAR bosses will look further into the situation and penalties to Harvick could be brought down later in the week. 
Bayne certainly thought Harvick’s move was intentional. 
“That’s a crappy way for Harvick to have to get in the Chase; to wreck somebody — what I believe to be on purpose” Bayne said. 
As for Harvick, he said it was just an accident. 
“As I pulled up, I didn’t even see the 6 (Bayne) up there and clipped him and shot him across the inside,” Harvick said. “It sucks, but it worked out.” Sponsored Links
